About me
I am a Technical Artist specializing in immersive VR development, combining expertise in Unity, C#, and Blender to create engaging virtual
experiences.
I bridge the gap between technical development and creative design, bringing both artistic vision and programming proficiency to each project.
With a diverse skill set spanning VR development, 3D modeling, and software engineering, I excel at finding innovative solutions to complex problems.
Challenging myself to turn difficult ideas into functional experiences through hands-on technical expertise and creative problem-solving is what I enjoy.

https://marvinschmidt002.github.io/proje.body:
360 Squash is a fast-paced squash inspired VR game me and some fellow students created during a 24h game jam on campus of Darmstadt University of Applied Sciences.

    


My tasks:

Coding one third of the game logic especially the ball movement.
Designing the art style and modeling the 3D models.
Creating the Particle effects.
Designing the game mechanics and the game loop.
Team management and coordination.
Integration of the different parts of the game.

https://marvinschmidt002.github.io/proje.body:
A Scriptable Object based Event System for Unity

    



Datatypes
First we establish the datatypes that we want to use for our events.

In addition to the input types, we also need a class to store the outputEvents because unity has different kind of built-in unity events, this will make more sense later.


Scriptable Object
Next lets take a look at the actual scriptable object that will hold the events.
First we establish some interfaces that we will use for the event and the listener to make sure that we can easily add new events and listeners in the future.
The event itself is rather simple, the most important part is that we are setting the input type here that will get synced across all listeners and invokers of the event.


Event Listener
Next we need a class that will listen to the event and invoke the correct unity event based on the input type.
For that we create the EventListenerData class that implements the IEventListener interface which handles the subscription and unsubscription of the event,
as well as the invocation of the event with the correct data type. The actual EventListener class is a MonoBehaviour that holds a list of EventListenerData objects
and makes sure they’re synced with the input type of the event. It also has a general response event that gets invoked when any event is invoked.


Event Invoker
Lastly we need a class that will invoke the event with the correct data type. This is just an example of how you could invoke the events with their matching data types.


Example
Here is an example of how you could use the event system in your project.
First we create a new scriptable event, in this case it carries a string value.

    


Next we create an event listener that listens to the event and invokes a unity event with the string value to change a text component directly without the
need of an additional script, since built-in unity events can access the public functions with matching parameter input types.

    


Lastly we just need to invoke the event with any string value we choose. In this case we are going to use the Event Invoker script from earlier.

    


That is it, now you can easily create new events and listeners without the need of additional scripts or references to other objects.
https://marvinschmidt002.github.io/proje.description: A Scriptable Object based Event System for Unity
https://marvinschmidt002.github.io/proje.title: Event System

https://marvinschmidt002.github.io/proje.body:
In the Reef is an educative underwater VR experience created for a museum as a group of four students during a semester project.
This is a vertical slice and not the full game, it serves merely as a proof of concept.

    


My tasks:

Coding lead of the project, responsible for almost all the code.
Designing the art style, creating shaders and quality checking the 3D models.
Handling the VR interactions and movement.
Integration of the different parts of the game.
All unity related tasks like setting up the project, lighting, and post-processing effects.


Swimming
I coded a swimming system that allows the player to move around in the water by moving their arms. The system is based on the player’s hand movement and direction. The player can swim forward, backward,
up and down by moving their hands in the water while holding the grab button.
The swimming system also checks if the motion vector is in a continuous direction by using the dot product, so the player can’t just move their hands in a circle to swim forward.


    
        
    

Corals
I modeled a low n high poly version of the coral and proceeded to bake the normals on the low poly model.

    



    


The coral is animated by using several shapekeys to both create idle moving aswell as eating animations.

    
        
    

These are being triggered by a trigger script that checks if the player is close enough to the coral or by the particles of the gun hitting the invisible collider in the middle of the coral.
The Trigger script is versatile and can handle many different ranges and targets in a single instance.


    


Visual Style
The visual style of the game is rather cartoonish and colorful. I created a shader that uses a toon ramp to shade the objects aswell as a gradient to give variation to the colors.

    


Additionally, I added the option to enable Caustics for the objects using the light direction and the objects normals aswell as voronoi noise to create the effect.

    
        
    

The style would not be complete without a skybox and post-processing effects. So I used a procedural skybox and added basic post-processing like fog and color grading.
I made sure not to use any expensive effects to keep the performance high.
https://marvinschmidt002.github.io/proje.description: A educative underwater VR experience to learn about coral reefs made for a museum.
https://marvinschmidt002.github.io/proje.title: In The Reef

https://marvinschmidt002.github.io/proje.body:
Jungle Creatures was a project created for design class at the University of Applied Sciences Darmstadt. The goal was to create an alien jungle with creatures in it for Spatial using Unity.
It was a group project with two other students.

    


My tasks:

Setting up the game logic using Spatials components.
Designing the art style and modeling most of the 3D models.
Creating the blockout.
building the map.
Creating the Shaders.
Team management and coordination.
All unity related tasks like lighting and post processing.


3D models
The first model I created was the alien jungle tree.

    

Followed by a simple rock.

    

Next was the alien creature.

    

and quite a bit more, like grass, bulbs for lighting, retopologizing of logs etc.

Map
For the map I wanted to create a dense jungle with some verticality to it. The goal was to reveal parts of the map as the player progresses through the jungle.

    


Shaders
The first shader I created was a skybox shader using Unitys URP shader graph.

    

Resulting in a highly customizable skybox.

    

The other Shader I made is a wind shader for the trees.

    

Resulting in a nice wind effect which can be customized with several variables.
https://marvinschmidt002.github.io/proje.description: A experience to meet creatures in an alien jungle
https://marvinschmidt002.github.io/proje.title: Jungle Creatures

https://marvinschmidt002.github.io/proje.body:
Music dodge is a game where you dodge obstacles to the beat of the music. This project was created for the application process of the University of Applied Sciences Darmstadt.

    


Obstacles
There is four different obstacles that spawn to the beat of the music. The player can dodge them by moving to the left or right, jumping and ducking.

    


To the Beat
To make the obstacles spawn to the beat of the music I used the audioSource data and the bpm of the song to calculate intervals for the obstacles to spawn.


Gameplay
Gameplay video (audio: Prince of Wales - Jealous):
https://marvinschmidt002.github.io/proje.description: A game where you dodge obstacles to the beat of the music.
https://marvinschmidt002.github.io/proje.title: Music Dodge

https://marvinschmidt002.github.io/proje.body:
A VR asian style RPG game created over the span of one semester in Unity.
For this project I created none of the 3D models, but everything else was done by me, including coding, game design, world layout, vr setup, etc.

    


World
The world I created is rather big including a castle, a village, a bamboo forest a cave and more.

    

Village:

    


Lightning Shrine:

    


Autumn Valley:

    


Bamboo Forest:

    


Castle:

    


Cave:

    



Magic System
The Magic System is based on elemental Ofudas (japanese paper talismans):

    


The Elements are very modular and are just declared in an enum, so integrating new elements is very easy.

Each Ofuda is a scriptable object that contains an element and four spells, their damage and their respective prefab.

Example Fire Ofuda:

    


Now the script handling the Ofudas is quite long but basicly it checks for when you grab an Ofuda using the VR grab socket, rolls a random owned element for it and applies the corresponding material.
Note in the following code snippets I will only show parts of the scripts to keep it digestible.

When you proceed to activate it, it will spawn the spell selection wheel.
Spell Selection Wheel: when you activate an Ofuda it records the position of the controller at that moment and opens a four way menu for you to select a spell.

    



After that the spell is depending on the type of spell either instantly spawned or incase it is a targeted spell spawned after you aim and confirm.
The aiming is done with a seperate system for each aiming type, for example the Meteor spell uses an arc raycast to show the path of the meteor.

//TODO: add video of casting spells

Behaviour Trees
The AI in the game is controlled by behaviour trees, which are a very modular way of controlling AI.
The behaviour tree is a tree of nodes that can be nested and are executed in a certain order.
(I would show code, but it would be too much to show here and deserves a section of its own at some point.)
The tree is built in a way that the AI can react to the player in different ways, for example if the player is in a certain range the AI will attack, if the player is out of range the AI will follow the player.

    
        
    

I created a behaviour tree system from the ground up and made a custom editor for it aswell.

    


To apply the tree to an AI you just add it to the AI-Agent like so:

    


The Dictionary handler here works as a form of communication between the behaviour tree and any other script, in this example the AI-Agent, it is used to read and write values to the tree.

AI-Agent
Since I mentioned the AI-Agent let me quickly explain what it does.
The AI-Agent is a script that is attached to every AI in the game, it handles the AI’s stats, the AI’s health and the AI’s target and targeting ranges like “IsInChaseRange”.
It also handles the Damage logic when the AI gets hit and notifies the behaviour tree if it is dead.
It also handles communication with the save system.

    



3rd Person Controller
The 3rd Person Controller is a bit of a separate thing from the rest of the game, it was only created as requirement for the project as requested by the teacher.
The controller is made up of two parts, the movement controller which lets you run around and jump.


    
        
    

and the combat controller which lets you attack in modular combos by using a list of scriptable objects.



    
        
    

Water Shader
The water shader I made using amplify, is an advanced shader using math to calculate accurate waves, in addition with refraction and depth to simulate water.

    
        
    

The node setup looks as following:

    


The Custom node GerstnerWave being the following code:
